Reviews.Author: Hussain Ahmadi
Reviews.Content: I got the this new awesome device recently and its been more than a week that I used it so I’d like to share with you all my thoughts about it. First have to say that I’m an owner of Kindle Fire (1st generation), iPad 2, iPad 3, iPad Air, Google Nexus 7 (2012), Samsung Galaxy Note 3, Samsung Galaxy S3, Kobo Arc and few more tablets that I have used in the past but those mentioned are still being used. So in my review I will be comparing this tablet to the others that I have where necessary.HARDWARE:I have to say that Amazon nailed it when it comes to the hardware of the device. The tablet feels very comfortable in hand, with its rubbery back. but the main attraction here is the gorgeous display. It is so beautiful, very clear and crispy. Even though the Kindle shows a slightly more yellowish whites compared to the iPad Air whites but the colors look slightly better to the eyes on the Kindle than the iPad. at least to my eyes. Tested many pics on both and Kindle had that slight edge when it comes to how pleasant the colors look. I have even read that many professional sites have already declared the Kindle as the more accurate tablet when it comes to colors than the rest, not to forget also that the Kindle is lighter than iPad Air. Another advantage that goes to the Kindle over the rest tablets is the sound, with dual speakers placed at the right places it just gives a very strong and pleasant sound makes your music and videos sound a lot better. The placement of power and volume buttons are odd at first but you will get used to them fast. Cant say much about the camera because I do not use tablets for taking pictures.SOFTWARE:I will write more about the software as I have not seen this enough covered by other reviewers. I will write the things I like and dislike when it comes to the software:Things I like:1- Special offers: yes, don’t raise your eyebrows. I just love it that whenever I want to unlock my Kindle there is something new rather than a boring wallpaper. I find the offers interesting and I hope Amazon show more book ads. they just look gorgeous on full screen.2- The Carousel: Big icons on a high resolution screen look really beautiful and you can remove whatever you don’t want to be there. A nice thing Amazon implemented was the suggestions below the books and apps in the carousel. I find this extremely useful.3- Email: I find myself using this email more than the other tablets for the following reasons. The following points might be small bits but to me they make the Kindle Email superior than the rest:  a- Conversation Mode: Where you see the whole email conversation with a particular account. Yes the iPad also got this but in Kindle it is way more organised.  All the conversation are in one page and you don’t need to click back and forth to read like the iPad, with just one click you can view one and hide rest. really cool.  b- Multiple Selection: Again this is available in all the tablets but it is superior in Kindle’s email. you can select the emails and you can even open one while the the selection is made and all that without erasing your selection. Very very useful. Many times on iPad when I select multiple emails to delete then I decide to check one of them my selection just goes and I have to reselect again. With the Kindle this does not happen anymore.  c- Zooming: This applies to emails written  directly and not within HTML frame or CS. On the iPad when I zoom the text I have then to move the cursor left and right to read the zoomed text. annoying to do that. On Kindle’s email when I zoom the text, the text just gets bigger and fits the page view nicely. No more do I need to go left and right.Really great job Amazon with the email.4- Implementation of Goodreads in the Kindle is the right direction towards making the Kindle tablet a true E-reading device. However, this implementation is not full and lots of things were left. For example you cannot update your reading status of a book. Amazon should address this along with goodreads to make this implementation fully functional so that I don’t need to go to goodreads website from the browser.5- Text to Speech Voices: The text to speech voices on this tablet is the best ever in the market. period. Unlike Apple’s dreadful robotic voice Siri or Samsung’s scary Voice on the kindle provide the most natural human like voices. I love all the four UK and US voices. It is very nice of Amazon to provide different options for the user to choose according to his own likings unlike Apple which only gives us one horrendous voice on the iPad although on its mac OS Apple has so many great voices to choose from.7- Recently opened Apps menu: With the new OS Amazon has introduced the new history menu that could be pulled up from within any application. This makes the multitasking easier and at one finger point.Things I don’t like:1- Book description: This was the major letdown for me with this Kindle. I had to dig and ask a lot to see how I could get to the book description of any book purchased from amazon. First you have to download the book. then open the book, then tab on the three lines on the upper left side to access the left side menu then click on the cover that appears there to see the description. phew!! Come on Amazon you have to do it better than this. on the Kindle Paperwhite you just tab and hold on a cover and the menu shows the book description whether the book is on your cloud or already downloaded to your device. I strongly feel this is a very important thing to us readers as it will make us decide which book to start reading. Amazon should really make the same kind of menu accessible on the carousel as well as in the device and cloud pages of books. THIS IS VERY VERY IMPORTANT. Have to mention that even Amazon’s iOS app lacks this feature while both other e-reading apps like Nook and Kobo have their book description in a very easy and nice way.2- Silk: it is a functional browser with all the basics however what I don’t like about it is that when you have more than two tabs opened the tabs keep reloading as if you were doing a page refresh! Why is that? maybe something need to be done in the settings? no idea but this tab loading is annoying and it prevents me from browsing the net specially when I want to open multiple tabs.3- Sometimes there is a slight lag when going through the carousel and this lag happens particularly when the device downloading something like a book or an app. It should be addressed.4- When I make multiple purchases on my computer and choose the HDX as the device for my books to be delivered to there is something wrong happens. I think sometimes the download in the device gets stuck and i have to remove all the queued book and redownload them again. This happens when I do that more than 10 books at a once. but when in batch it goes smoothly. So Amazon should address multiple book download pushes from other devices to the HDX.5- Text to Speech accessibility: I think all the books that support text to speech should have the play button within. Why do I need to enable accessibility in order for the kindle to read the book to me? This is annoying. I don’t need accessibility enabled. I just need one play button in my book menu for the kindle to read it. Moreover, there is no short cut for accessibility. Not that I know. i have to go into settings and enable it there every time I want kindle to read to me. On iPad there is  the option to press the home button 3 times to enable it. Kindle should use a similar shortcut or even better make the play button available within the books without the need to enable text to speech from accessibility.6- Definition and Speak buttons: While kindle has the definition option within the book it lacks it in the other parts of the OS and apps. on the iPad you can highlight a word and get the option of the definition or the word to be read to you. unfortunately kindle does not offer this feature not even in its Silk browser.7- Sideloaded apps: This is not Amazon’s fault but had to mention it. When you sideload an application the icon of the application looks blurry in the carousel. This has to do with the icon's resolution being not high enough as the apps we get from the Amazon store. Not a big deal but yea it is annoying.So as you can see the things I don’t like are all software based and with the right update and tweaks Amazon can make this great tablet better. Among the things I don’t like I specially find No.1 and No.5 the most that goes in my wish list of being addressed sooner than later.This device is really good. it has so many other good features like the Mayday, Freetime etc but I personally won’t be using them.I also hope Amazon work with Google in future to offer Google apps like Youtube etc on their store. I know there are alternatives but to get the official app is always  better.I find the Amazon Kindle Fire HDX with its ultra HD resolution and great text to speech voices to be THE TABLET any reader should get. You cannot go wrong with it. I prefer it over the iPad Air or mini for reading books. The HDX along with the Paperwhite are winners all the way if reading is the main purpose. I would give The Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 a 4 out of 5. with the right updates that rating should go up. I will update this review in the future the more I use the tablet.
Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire HDX 8.9, The best tablet in the market for readers

Reviews.Author: TK1244
Reviews.Content: This is a christmas gift for my mom.  She lives in a rural area, and I wanted her to have 4G thru AT&T; because my tablet receives great service at her house.  I went through all the push-ups on the new Kindle HDX to add a line to our existing AT&T; account as prompted thru the Kindle.  I received an email with a web order ID and still spent 2 hours+ on the phone (between 3 very friendly and helpful reps and transfers) to get it activated.  Save yourself some time - skip the on board instructions and just call 1-888-444-4410 and go straight to the source for adding a new line with a data plan to your existing service.  Hope this helps someone stay off the phone for a bit!!!
Reviews.Title: 4G thru AT&T;?  Please read and save yourself some time!

Reviews.Author: rpv
Reviews.Content: Overall Summary: Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 is an awesome hardware and has an excellent software system if you are on Amazon ecosystem.Broadly I see different categories of people in vertical basis- by size: phones (4-5"), mini tablets 7-8", tablets 9-10"- by OS: Android, iOS, FireOS and maybe Windows 8- by cost: cost conscious and gadget freaks who have no care for the money and pile it on the plastic card- by disease: who have TACS [ Tablet Acquisition and Craving Syndrome ]SPEC COMPARISON:To begin, let me deep dive into specs of a broad range of top tablets as of now. -- Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1", iPAD Air 9.7", Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1", Google Nexus 10" and Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 8"I am throwing in the Tab 8 as I feel there will be a segment of people who are inclined for it in favor or HDX. Reading the specs for WHAT matters to YOU most is critical. I know for some people, the weight matters, for some size. For some the SD card is a deal breaker. So read on..key_specs of leading tablets as of 2013: { model: resolution, ppi, CPU, RAM, Flash memory, SD_card,  camera spec, weight, OS_type, size, charging/sync port type, GPS:y/n }Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" model:  2560 x 1600, 339 ppi, Snapdragon 800 2.2 GHz quad-core, 2 GB RAM, 16/32/64 Flash Memory, No microSD card, 8MP rear-facing camera, front-facing 720p HD camera,  374 grams, FireOS 3.0,  9.1 x 6.2 x 0.31 inches, microUSB, GPS:no [cellular versions have GPS]Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1" 2014 Edition: 2560x1600, 299 ppi, 1.9GHz Samsung Exynos 5420 Quad-Core Processor, 3GB RAM, 16/32 GB Flash Memory, microSD slot:yes(upto 64 GB), 8MP rear camera and 2 MP front-facing camera, 560 grams, Android 4.3 Jelly Bean OS, 9.57 x 6.75 x 0.31 inches, microUSB, GPS:yes. S-Pen (flagship),iPAD Air 9.7" (2013):  2048 x 1536 resolution, 264 ppi, A7/M7/64 bit processor,  Flash Memory: 16/32/64/128 GB, SD Card:no, 5 MP back, 1.2 MP front, 469 grams, iOS 7, 9.4 x 6.6 x 0.29 in, lightning port, GPS:no [cellular versions have GPS]Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1" model: 1280 x 800, 149 ppi, Intel Atom 1.6GHz Z2560 dual-core processor, 1GB RAM, Flash Memory: 16/32GB,  microSD slot: yes upto 64 GB, 3.2MP rear-facing, 1.3MP front-facing, 510 grams,  Android 4.2.2, 9.57 x 6.93 x 0.31 in,  micoUSB port:yes, GPS:yesGoogle Nexus 10" model: 2560 x 1600, 300 ppi, CPU: Dual-core A15, 2GB RAM, 16/32 GB, SD:no, rear:5 MP, front:1.9 MP, 603g, 10.4" x 7" x 0.35", mcroUSB, GPS:yesSamsung Galaxy Tab 3 8" model: 1280 x 800, 189 ppi, Exynos 1.5GHz dual-core processor, 1.5GB RAM, Flash memory: 16/32GB, microSD slot: yes upto 64 GB, 5MP rear-facing, 1.3MP front-facing, 309 grams, Android 4.2, 8.26 x 4.87 x 0.29 in, microUSB port:yes, GPS: yesYou should come up with three top three specs you want and should be able to nail it down with the above spec. If you have doubts shoot me a comment, I can help!HOW IT FARES WITH COMPETITION:The screen size is a bit odd at 8.9". Every hardware manufacturer seems to have a pet with different sizes.  Three things about the Kindle HDX that are outstanding are  the screen resolution, resolution, and resolution. Stunning is the word to describe it.  HDX  is what Amazon calls beyond HD screen resolution. Sound is also awesome with Dolby Digital Plus audio+dual stereo speaker+microphone. I like the fact that Amazon Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" has a standing Leather Origami case aided with camera assist. Sliding the case triggers camera app.I have seen screens of all the tablets I have spec above and HDX 8.9" color, contrast, vivid nature of screens definitely outperforms all. This is mainly because of the LCD technology used by Kindle surprisingly beating out  even iPAD air. This has been verified by lot of gadget blogs in gory technical details. Google Nexus model currently in the market is an aging technology (yes, 1 year lot of new things happen in technology).Fire OS 3.0 on Kindle HDX is tightly integrated with cloud, has enterprise software. Fire OS 3.0 is Amazon's forked Android operating system.  It is extremely media centric and cannot be compared to iOS and Android. I feel it is comparing apples and oranges. If you are a media hound, get Kindle HDX. You will not be disappointed. If you are someone who likes to root, hack the OS, develop apps, get the Android. If all you care if design and are immersed in iTunes you know what to get.GENERAL TAKEAWAY:Excellent for browsing/reading emails/reading books. Solid Amazon media devices, this is not a Android tablet. Lot of my friends are confused and have vastly different expectations of Fire HD or HDX.  One thing do bear is mind, Kindle Fire devices are NOT Android devices. Amazon has changed the core of Android front end so that it is significantly different. As long as you understand it and have that in mind, you are good to go. For a large number of people in the world, this does not matter. The UI for example is centered on Amazon experience - books/music/video you have purchased on Amazon. If you live breathe Amazon like me these days, Kindle Fire HDX is plain awesomeness.SCREEN RESOLUTION:Just awesome. Period.SPEED:No issues, I streamed a movie in HD, no stuttering, no stops. It was a smooth experience. The quad-core processor should definitely help. Played few video games, not much heat/issues noticed.MEMORY:On the RAM front 2GB is plenty, no complaints.  However, having no SD card is a bummer for many of the vendors. Apple/Amazon/Google all of them don't have microSD card slot. Can you see a trend. All of them are cloud providers (iTunes/Amazon ecosystem/Google ecosystem) and they will each benefit if you buy books/music/video from them and not bring your own collection onto an SD card. In this respect Samsung is great as you can have multiple microSD cards ($50 for 64 GB) and use it as you wish.EASE OF USE:Very easy to use. It's a Amazon media device. Some people call it a Sears catalog for 21st century. Whatever, the gorgeous hardware makes it easy to consume media. It is a media consumption device. For amazon lovers this is just breathtaking - the interface and the User Experience. Books/Music/Video/E-Commerce absolutely just suits.APPLICATION ECOSYSTEM:Again bear in mind, this has Amazon app store, not Google Play store. What this means to you. Most of Google services apps will be missing-- Gmail, Chrome, YouTube, Google Earth, Google Maps, Google Drive, Google Calendar, Google Translate. Amazon has its own browser/email apps. For someone who has not purchased a tablet before, this is a great start. If you are used to an Android device for several years, this may send you a shock ripple through your spine. So beware of these limitations. Few other missing things obviously include Google Now and Google voice based Navigation (GPS is absent in wifi model, so this is obviously moot, but in cellular models this applies).  Amazon app store has most of prominent apps, so this is not a `big' concern.If you have bought apps in Google Play store, you have to buy them again in Amazon ecosystem - their appstore. All updates takes longer in Amazon to roll out than in Google playstore. Again these may not matter to a general public. People have debated if the absence of Google Playstore is due to Amazon's policy or google's policy of unbranded device. In either case, I feel customers are at a loss.BATTERY:I have not used extensively, so cannot comment. In my several hours of use, I did not find any major issue. Will report as I test for few weeks.USEFULNESS:Very useful if you are in the Amazon ecosystem. It is really lightweight and it is a great strength. Handholding books is not that painful anymore. Watching Prime videos on long road trips is a big plus. The resolution and text is awesome for reading books. It almost feels in a surreal way that the books are more real than a hardcover. X-Ray provides more detailed contextual information for books/music/video. I don't use it that much as I like not to be distracted. Mayday help is also something I have not needed yet. This is mainly meant for new people and it will be definitely a hit with first timers.  Overall I give the Kindle HDX a definite recommend if you are on the Amazon ecosystem.Do ask me questions, I love to answer questions from readers of the review.
Reviews.Title: Exceptional device for Amazon ecosystem

Reviews.Author: burghboy
Reviews.Content: I normally do not post reviews as most of the time I am not that impressed with a product to take the time to write about it in detail.  This is the exception The Kindle Fire HDX 8.9. I have had all of the previous versions of the kindle fires and thought they were good for movies, books, shopping at Amazon & music along with a few apps that were popular, but they lacked the hardware/spec/polish to be a great internet browser and tablet overall.  I have used the Ipad 1 & 2 in the past and even those older versions surfed the net better than the previous Kindle Fires most of the time.  With the addition of all the apps for Ipads and the straight android market it was tough for the older Fires to compete directly as a top quality tablet.  I never bothered in the past to side load apps as I figured it was difficult and a bother and back then I was just using all the apps I needed on my Samsung Galaxy 3 from the android market.  (More on Side loading apps later on the Fire)NOW...the new Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 changes everything that I did not like.  I was able to purchase it at Staples with a $50 off coupon and for $329 I received the 16 gb version that now  come with a charging kit.  The old ones did not.  That is a difference of $170 compared to an $499 Ipad Air 16GB.  Even at $379 it is still a saving of $120.First impression was WoW the amazing light weight of the new tablet...Awesome!  Next the screen is amazing.  When I say that, I mean the best I have ever seen on any tablet including the new IPAD Air (more on that direct comparison later).  I was hoping that these 2 improvements would not be the only thing that was upgraded as the software, apps and processor needed to be drastically improved to compete with the other new tablets coming out.The great news is that the silk browser is much improved as well as the whole operating system.Fire HDX 8.9 vs the Ipad Air I tested the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 against my friends new Ipad Air in surfing the internet 1st. Side by Side i would go to various sites on both tablets to see if there was a big difference in speed.  They were both going over wifi and to my surprise the speed was basically the same (really good). Sometimes the kindle was slightly faster and sometime the Ipad was, but it was so negligible in most cases that I would not even notice it if not comparing them side by side.  The great news to me was that the New Kindle was equal to the new Ipad Air in surfing the net which in the past it was not!My next comparison was to look at the screens while surfing and also watching movies.  The Kindle Fire screen was indeed brighter and clearer in both movies and web sites in almost all cases.  The Kindle Fire's screen is slightly smaller, but for watching movies in HD horizontally they were the same size on both devices because the Ipad has the black bars that limit it on I am assuming HD formatted movies. (I could be wrong in that maybe it is not always the case with the formatting).  The Kindle Fire's coloring, brightness and clarity in side by side streaming movies with the Air was just plain and simple better.  In darker scenes you could clearly make out details on the fire that I could not on the the Air. The Fire's screen looked brighter and clear with great colors that just stood out! I tried several scenes in 2 different movies and the result was always in favor of the Kindle Fire.  I was shocked at the advantage as it was quite a bit better. (the Air has a good screen, just not as good as the new fires!)  Also the Kindle with a Prime Membership lets you download some movies/tv shows for viewing offline later.  It is not all movies/tv shows but there is enough for now to keep you occupied for several trips and hopefully they will continue to add more in the future. They let you chose the standard size or 720 or 1080 but each step up takes up more room on your tablet and takes longer to download.  I have also heard that some have time limits as to how long you can have them downloaded but I have not yet experienced that with the shows I have downloads. (one negative is they do not tell you which movies are downloadable??? So you have no way of knowing until you click on it. Hopefully they will add that to the search option in the future in Prime)  I just also want to mention IMDb for movies is something I thought I wouldn't use much, but I am really starting to like it. It tells you all about any actors on screen and also add's trivia about the movie or scene.  It makes me want to rewatch older classic movies just to learn more about them!Ok, so far the Fire is lighter in weight, with a better screen and the speed when surfing the net was equal!  I am really impressed so far.  Now comes the area that bothered me in the past and almost had me going for an Ipad Air..lack of Apps in the closed off Amazon market.  Now do not get me wrong Amazon has a ton of popular Apps that I am guessing would satisfy 75% of the people who would consider buying a Kindle Fire in the 1st place.  They have all the popular games and apps that most people use.  But they also do not have some that Google and Apple do provide.  For example Amazon had my CBS sports fantasy Football app, but did not have ESPN's fantasy football app. along with Direct TV Sunday ticket! This drove me crazy as I wanted both on my new amazing Fire screen!  So I decided to try to side-load these into the Kindle and they worked! I will not go into that process, but It was relatively easy to do in just a few steps.  This process gives me access to most/all of the android apps!!!  This is a great way to get all the apps you might not find in the amazon Apps store.  I will always use Amazon apps 1st (since they approve them), but then sideload ones they do not have in their store.  This really solves one of the biggest complaints you will hear about the Kindle Fire from techie/experts!  It may take a little work at first to figure out how to sideload the apps, but once you do it is a pretty simple task.Lastly, I just received the OS update 3.1 for the fire and it added Goodreads and also Collections to the Fire.  It added more improvements but I did not have a chance to use the others to this point.  Goodreads is great if you like reading and seeing what others recommend or are reading!  Collections lets you add Books or Apps into Groups which makes it much easier to find things on your tablet.  The apps collections can go right on the Home Screen of the Kindle which is a nice touch that other tablets already maybe have (apple?).  There are other improvements that I will try to come back and update at a later time when I have a chance to use them.In summarizing the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9- It has surpassed my expectations period.  I find it can go side by side with the new Ipad Air in almost every respect and even beat it in screen quality, weight and price $170 less!!!!  You can almost buy the smaller HDX 7inch for that if you catch a sale.  I cannot recommend the 8.9 enough as I am for the 1st time really impressed with the whole package.  It can do everything well and has the screen, processor, OS and price that puts it ahead or at least equal to the new IPAD air.  Amazon with Prime & the HDX 8.9 is a killer combination of great Hardware/Software/2 day free shipping/Apps/Games and finally Great Amazon Support!  The Mayday Button (Help) is amazing. I am pretty good at using technology and I used it a few times to help change a few settings on the tablet instead of searching  for the settings.  The customer service rep. was online in a video box on my table in 20 seconds and help me find the settings quickly.  Another amazing aspect of this tablet is that it is great for novices as well as people who like technology and want to try to sideload apps for example.  I just do not see anything on the market at this price with this many great and unique features that comes close to comparing to the HDX 8.9 Fire.
Reviews.Title: The Fire 8.9 HDX exceeded my expectations and equals or beats the Ipad Air in many respects at a cheaper price! Love it Amazon

Reviews.Author: Doug
Reviews.Content: Amazon definitely seemed to try and exude a more premium vibe this year. I think they got a lot of feedback since last year's HD which came in a black box marked Kindle Fire with a pull tab. This time they actually delivered a retail box complete with charger so you got some amount of unboxing pleasure. It did appear as if the tablet was shipped in sleep mode since the first thing I did was attach an Origami case and it woke it up with 4% battery left. Like always it comes pre logged in with your account which is that nice little touch so you're almost able to just run with it. I say almost because you need to get software update first which is pretty par the course for electronics these days.The first thing that you notice when pulling it out of the box is how crazy light it is. Feels much closer in weight to a 7" than to the 10" tablets, in fact last year's iPad feels like a tank now. The next thing that was immediately noticeable was the touch response. Note I'm talking about that few millisecond lag between pressing the screen and something happening. Not everyone seems to notice but it's always been an issue with Android that this was a bit long, the HDX doesn't exhibit this and I'm fairly sure this is a software change not just the hardware but either way it just feels really good and really fast. The was especially noticeable on the keyboard. There are no hiccups with the way Fire OS and the SoC handle the UI which coming off N7, Fire HD and older iPads it feels good.The screen is obnoxious. It's probably the best screen on anything really. Realistically the resolution bump isn't noticeable but the color, contrast and brightness sure are. I'm very happy they put a lot of effort into those aspects because it makes it a very well rounded display, it excels at everything. The speakers seem to be the same as the ones in the HD, that is to say the best tablet speakers around. The main difference is they got moved to the top so you don't obstruct them with your grip. Which leads me to another point which is that this tablet really wants to be used in a specific orientation. The camera is the only real indicator so it's easy to mess up, but unlike the KFHD which could be held however the back buttons demand landscape or you can't find them. They are mighty comfortable because you don't have to change your grip to use them when you get there but if you use it in portrait like I like to the volume buttons can be hard to track down. Sleep/wake is solved by getting a case because I immediately attached one and never have had to physically press that button even once.The Fire OS UI has changed a little bit. It still looks the same but things have been tweaked. If you are one of those who hates the carousel you can swipe up to get a grid view (the most recent 10 items are always shown at the bottom). There are more categories of things across the top as games and apps got separated and the recommendations are much smaller (you can still turn those off in settings). There is also a multitasking view if you swipe up from the button bar that is smart enough to multitask between books and media in addition to apps. FireOS 2 had little things that were missing that could make navigation a pain but this version stands on it's own in terms of features and doesn't feel lacking compared to stock Android.I first downloaded all my previous apps from my old KFHD. These are easily accessible from the app menu, you don't even need to visit the store, just go the cloud tab and you have a list of everything you own and just tap on things to download. The rest of my media is mostly in the cloud to save space but the process to download is just as easy. The one thing I had to re-create was my browser settings, those don't seem to cloud-sync. My old HD had a few sideloaded apps that I needed, so the first step was to go to settings and allow installing of 3rd party apps. Then I could go to dropbox.com and get dropbox (because for whatever reason it's not in the store proper), and I also grabbed a few of the latest Google APKs off the web. Installing is simply a matter of downloading the APK and tapping it (no PC required). I couldn't get certain login features to work even with the GoogleLoginService APK but the apps work and I don't need to be logged into to Youtube/Google maps so I didn't bother trying to fix that.Last time I loaded Chrome and Gmail. FireOS 2 had a lousy mail app and the preinstalled Silk kinda sucked (it got an update later than vastly improved it). They've done a lot of work since then to the point where sideloading other things feels unnecessary (I still use Chrome for testing at work but I wouldn't have bothered otherwise). The mail app is basic but does everything I want (read threaded emails and write them). Silk especially has come a long way, this version is branched off Chromium version 25 so while it's missing a few experimental web APIs (Google's WebRTC work) it works with pretty all the latest standards (WebGL included). It also now tells you when it grabbed an accelerated version of a page. Latest Chrome benches better but Silk on an HDX is still faster than Chrome on pretty much any other device.This one also features a rear camera. It's an appreciable 8MP with flash, probably won't replace your smartphone but for a tablet it's actually pretty good. It does better than my 5th gen iPod Touch so if you really need a camera it'll do in a pinch. It has all the normal features you expect, touch-focus, HDR, panorama modes and 1080p video. The camera app is surprisingly good, it comes with a myriad of quick edit features, filters, touchups, stickers, drawing tools, and even a meme-maker. I was expecting a lot less but they put a surprising amount of work into this.Some may be annoyed to learn that this model doesn't feature HDMI out. I wish they kept it because it's cheap and works with everything but Miracast is certainly a better overall option. I got a Netgear push2TV which is the only device specifically cited to work with the HDX right this moment. It's a little box that plugs in to a display via HDMI and uses a USB power source. It's pretty simply but I needed to update the firmware first (otherwise the HDX wouldn't recognize it) which involves downloading firmware from the website, having it create a temporary network and then uploading the file to it. I did this all on the tablet just for proof that you could since that would be a no-no on iOS but Android is pretty flexible and FireOS doesn't take that away. Once that was done I needed to go into setting and set up display mirroring. It's strangely hidden but it was very easy to do once I had my box updated. The output was pretty high quality with about a half second of lag. Note that it seems to squish the 2560x1600 into a 1080p which pillar boxes it and scales it down (even on my 2560x1600 display). I think that's a Miracast limitation or a limitation of the box itself but I think it would probably do the same thing over HDMI. The box was a bit pricey, about $55 and it needs 2 cable but I think as long as Miracast gains traction these should become smaller cheaper dongles that are powered via HDMI. In any case that's what's available right now but it's much more convenient that cables it's just a pity your forced into it for video out. Apparently they'll also have a second-screen app for Playstation consoles that works like a Chromecast as part of Fire OS 3.1 but that's not available yet.The last interesting thing is the Origami case. I couldn't decide if I liked it or not at first but now I definitely do. To be perfectly honest, it has a learning curve. It's very cleverly designed, it can fold into 2 different positions to hold the tablet horizontal or vertical and attaches magnetically. The nice part is is also magnetizes to itself in the folded position which makes it extremely stable compared to other tablet cases but you need to practice a bit to get the folds right because it isn't obvious at first. The Kindle also attaches magnetically which makes detaching it really easy unlike the smart cover for the HDX. This is good because it's a bit heavy and you may not always want it on. Since it folds it's not rigid like the HD's cover so you have to peel it back instead of open it like a book. When you hold it, the magnetic cover swings around and attaches to the back of itself which helpful except one glaring design flaw: it covers the back buttons meaning you have to lift it up to use the volume buttons (sleep/wake is handled by the magnetic attach points so it doesn't matter). Also when vertical you can only use it rotated right as the USB cord will obstruct in left rotation position. The final nifty little thing is you can push the HDX up in the case. This is because the camera isn't exposed but when you push it up it clicks into a position and this automatically launches the camera app no matter what you where doing, though sometimes is can take a couple seconds depending on if the app was hibernated. I really like this feature and really wish more things incorporated a quick camera feature like it. It just makes it that much easier to capture something in the moment. So it has some highs and some lows but I definitely recommend it, it's just a lot to take in for what you'd expect was a simply case. It did set me back $55 for a black, polyurethane though with an even more expensive leather one above that.After messing around with it for a whole day I was barely breaking 80% on the battery meter. At the current rate it will likely fall around the 10-12 hours Amazon advertises. Apparently when reading that number can jump to 18 but I'm not much of a tablet reader so I probably won't test that. The initial charge took maybe 3-4 hours to go from 4% to 100%.If you thought Amazon was just putting out cheap tablets I'd encourage you to take another look as this is a whole different beast that the KFHD (which itself was a massive step from the original). If the Kindle was a cheap tablet and the HD was a budget tablet with nice hardware this is very premium hardware that happens to be cheap. I was disappointed that they raised the price $80 but they definitely made that $80 go a long way. Spec-wise it's an iPad killer but it's still a lot cheaper which is what I like about it. I'll admit I don't really care much about tablet apps and games, I use my tablet for looking things up, reading email/social media, music, videos, web-surfing and web development. I also use Amazon a lot so this was really a no-brainer and if you're anything like me (a tech-slobbering deal-hunter who realizes the futility of convergence) I'd say it's a must-have. So I'm very happy with what they put out this year, it feels like a big step up from the HD.I gave it 4 because Amazon still has some catch-up to work on with their app store and basic apps.  I'd really like to see speech-to-text options as well as better syncing of browser options . I'd really like to see better mapping software options since Amazon does have their own API but strangely don't use it themselves.  The HDX doesn't have a compass or GPS on the wifi version unlike the Nexus 7 and a myriad of other dirt cheap tablets which I think this is a huge oversight.  But the final thing is the lack of update support.  I was highly disappointed with the way the original and now HD have been treated as far as updates go.  If Bezos says we're not on the upgrade treadmill then please port some of those features back and give my old device new life.  At some point it's okay to move on but when your new HD has software features last-year's didn't and the internals on the 8.9 HD are still better that's highly problematic.
Reviews.Title: Great Upgrade, Very Impressed

Reviews.Author: Jeremy Roper "perpetual student"
Reviews.Content: I've put about 12 hours of use into my Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 (with 64 GB and Wi-Fi only) at this point and am very satisfied. I've been interested in the Fire since launch but have held off because of lack of storage space (I want my music collection on it, which alone is over 30 gb, for one thing).I know there's been some irritation about it not being the same as Android. They never advertised it that way, and I think that shows a lack of effort to actually learn about the product before you spend hundreds of dollars on it. There are similarities to Android, but this OS is truly distinct. Amazon has always been geared toward media consumption, so it should come as no surprise that this is a media consumption device (I mean, really, that's what Kindles have been from the very beginning). It seems misguided to be bothered because of uninformed expectations. If you're looking for something other than media consumption, look elsewhere. But buying something like this without doing some research first? That doesn't make sense at all.I want to give this 4.5 stars, but that's unfortunately not an option, and it doesn't quite warrant 5 stars (yet, at least). I've used multiple Kindle devices and almost every Apple product, as well as Android phones and tablets and feel I have a pretty good foundation for comparison. The HDX 8.9 falls in a category of its own. Overall, I'm almost entirely pleased, and have only run into a few hiccups, mostly with the software. I'll explain the hiccups first to get those out of the way, then discuss what I love. Will update if necessary.***Not so great:- I got an error when it attempted to update during setup, and didn't think to do it right away (my fault). This may have prevented some of my problems, but not sure.- The software was a bit slow initially, which was disappointing because it's advertised as among the fastest of tablets (if not THE fastest). For example: App store, cloud music player (more on this later), adjusting settings, and viewing a PDF (the first I tried; the others were flawless). I was in the same room as my router, and I have reliably fast internet, so it's unlikely to be a Wi-Fi or connection issue.- The music player. I want all my music on the device, which is currently in the cloud so I tried downloading it. I couldn't find an apparent "download all" option, so I had to queue it artist by artist for about 10 GB before I went to bed. It was late and I didn't try Mayday, but I probably will when I get home. In addition, it was very slow and has frozen a couple of times when I try to load my music library, and ended up restarting. This may be an initial "indexing" thing, especially since I have a fairly large library. It took about 20 minutes to finally access what I had downloaded last night. Now, however, the problem is resolved. -- ***UPDATE on this in comments***- The App Store seems a bit cluttered.- The display flickered 3 times in the first 30 minutes, but never since.What I love:- The screen is phenomenal. It's fun to look at just because it's so pretty. No "blue haze," so maybe they were able to address that before this model shipped. I've tried to see it but just can't. Touch response is excellent as well; sensitivity and accuracy are top-notch.- Processing speed is excellent, except for the few problems I initially experienced, which seem to be resolved.- The media bar along the top is great; unlike Android or iOS, I don't have to go search in the menu for the different content apps.- Sound is fantastic. I've never heard speakers on a tablet that even come close. It's better than a lot of laptops. Wired and bluetooth headphones have great sound as well.- Keyboard: this might be a weird one, but especially after discovering Swype I've been very disappointed with traditional touch keyboards. I was holding onto a faint hope that Swype would be available and am very pleased it is.- Wi-Fi speed is better than any mobile device I've used. Bluetooth seems to work without a hitch as well.- Cameras are clear and responsive. I hate the way my phones always take about 3 seconds to actually take the picture. Not an issue with the HDX 8.9.- Interface: I took a step back from what I was used to with Android, as I knew this wouldn't quite be the same. With that in mind, I am very pleased.- Prime Video works well and downloads relatively quickly. I'd like more selection but I also took the time to learn that they have a limited selection currently, which they're working on expanding.- Battery life appears to be as advertised. It's perfectly satisfactory, but after I run the battery down I'll update if necessary. Turn the Wi-Fi antenna off when you're not connected and it stretches a bit further. **UPDATE** - Finally ran the battery down from full charge to 15% after 12 hours of continuous use mixed between email, streaming video, web browsing, and LOTS of time downloading music from the cloud. Battery life impresses me well enough.- Integration with Prime features. I love that my Prime membership keeps going further and further beyond free 2-day shipping.- Little-to-no bloatware (depending on how you define it). I hate my android phones for this reason.- The price is incredible. I though a few times about an iPad Mini (w/ Retina) or iPad Air, but I could buy a decent new laptop for that price. Not looking to wipe out my savings for a tablet.Wish List/So-so features:- More customizability in settings. The collections option that they're supposed to roll out soon would be nice. I'd love an EQ adjustment in music and video as well - not all songs/videos/speakers/headphones are created equal.- Get rid of the matte finish on the back. Personal preference.- Not in love with the carousel home screen, though I may change my mind.- Smoother experience downloading music and videos - particularly music.- Better app selection. Most essentials are there, but hopefully this will expand.- I'm interested in the Second Screen feature. I can already play Amazon content on my TV, so hopefully this is something where I could send any content on the device to the screen. If not, I'll find it less than impressive.***I consider the iPad a media consumption device -- it grew out of the iPhone and iPod Touch, which sprang from the classic iPods, and they were all designed for media use. I think that's the HDX 8.9's closest competitor.  Aside from having more apps (not surprising if it was the first major device and has at least a three-year head start on the Fire) and being trendy from the start, I don't think the iPad has much of a leg up on the HDX. This device is faster and lighter, with an amazing display and a price substantially lower. Android was designed for more variable use, so go there if you want to do more work than play on your tablet. If I'm going to work much, I will do it on my laptop, which is really not much bigger.Altogether, I love my Kindle Fire HDX 8.9. It would be 5 stars if it weren't for a few bumps I've run into so far. But I expect it will only get better with a little time.
Reviews.Title: Impressed, and will probably only get better.

Reviews.Author: Sherri Griffin
Reviews.Content: I am not a tech person so if you want a tech savvy review, just ignore me.Mission: I needed a good e-reader for textbooks and research, but I wanted more functions than just an e-reader could provide.Screen: I am an Apple Snob and I won't lie: I wanted an iPad mini. I'm heavily invested in the Apple ecosystem, but I really needed a good e-reader and a good tablet for school. The iPad is a great tablet, but I kept seeing people saying that it wasn't a great e-reader. As an apple user, I can't deny that my eyes are always feeling strained while reading on my Macbook Air for long periods of time, so I started looking at other products. I'm really glad I went with the Kindle because is a big improvement for reading.Operating system: It is also extremely simple to operate and I haven't had any issues learning how to use the Kindle. In fact, it makes the apple IOS look extremely complicated-- which it isn't.Battery Life: It kills my Macbook Air. Destroys. Murders. Whatever adjective that means the Kindle's battery is way better. I can average 4-6 hours on my laptop off the charger, but the Kindle will last all day with mixed use.Size: I'm really glad that I went with the 8.9. It's bigger than the iPad mini, but I felt like the Kindle 7 would be too small. Even though I have small hands, the Kindle 8.9 is not too big and definitely not too heavy-- it's extremely light even with the (poetic) cover attached. I can easily hold it in one hand while reading. It's also a good size for watching movies and it's still perfect for playing games. The only downside is typing-- unless you have BIG hands or you like to peck--- use your computer!Reading: It has all the features of the Kindle e-books (highlighting, translation, search functionality, notes), but it is an LCD screen so it's not backlit like the paperwhite. However, my eyes seem to be fine with it especially with the abundant reading options. For instance, I was reading in the evening and as it got darker my eyes started to feel tired. I simply changed from a white to a black background and my eyes immediately felt better. Reading is SO MUCH BETTER than my Macbook Air. There are LOTS of books to choose from (including many free books)-- I've downloaded nearly two dozen books and I've only paid for 3 of them. Yay!Movies and Audio: No lag, excellent picture quality. Some people have said they haven't been able to get all the movies they've wanted to see, but I haven't ran into anything I can't watch... yet. There are a good selection of Prime videos you can watch for free and also cheap rentals. X-ray is pretty cool.The sound is EXCELLENT. Seriously, surprisingly good.Apps and Games: A lot of people seem to complain about the lack of apps, but everything I wanted was available and all but one of them were FREE. Granted, I do like a lot of the more popular apps (pinterest, facebook, evernote), so if you want something really specific then it may not be there. As for games, I got Angry Birds Rio for free and the response time is excellent. We also Real Racing 3 (Free) and the graphics were awesome and it was easy to play with no lag.Internet: The responsiveness to open pages is initially slower than my Macbook Air, but it isn't a huge difference. It seems to improve the more you visit the site. You have options to use different browsers: google, bing, and a few others. I'm a google addict so I didn't really look at anything else.Shopping: Strangely enough this is where I was disappointed. I was trying to find an e-book and I could get to the main shopping page which would show all the books in the series, but when I clicked on the book I wanted the page would just never load. The tablet did not freeze-- I could backspace out of the loading process. I restarted the Kindle, and I waited around, but this is still the case 24 hours later. I ended up buying the book on my computer and linked it to my kindle. This also happened when I was looking at movies-- it just kind of refuses to upload certain pages in the Kindle Store, but most have no problem.Camera: I never intend on using the camera, but I did just for you. It's surprisingly good. Definitely comparable to my iPhone with both the front and back cameras. It is no where near the level of my Lumix camera (thank good-- I spent too much money on it!), but it's definitely respectable.Mayday: Beats me. I haven't had to use it.I am really happy that I bough this instead of the iPad mini or Air and I saved myself a butt load of money. Thanks, Amazon! :)
Reviews.Title: Apple Snob Converted: Great e-reader, battery life, audio, camera and more!

Reviews.Author: Ryan Manning
Reviews.Content: So you're debating buying a tablet, doing your research, and then you see an advertisement for the Kindle Fire HDX? What the heck is it? What's different between it and every other android-based tablet out there? Why should I buy it? Hopefully I can give you a less “technical” perspective on the differences between android tablets and the Kindle Fire HDX and why you would or wouldn’t want to buy one! Let's cover the highlights:What is it?- It's a tablet...based off the android platform but running Amazon's proprietary firmware. What does that mean? It means you can run android apps but they have to be purchased through the amazon app store and not the Google play store (which isn't available on a Kindle Fire).Pros:- The screen is amazing, hands down the best I’ve seen in a long time.- Battery life is decent, however standby time could be improved (a week at most).- Integration with the Amazon app store and Prime instant video was very seamless and easy to use.- The interface is surprisingly easy to navigate, although there are some inconsistencies (ie. the back button moving between apps) that could be improved with software updates.- Memory and CPU were actually quite spectacular and should provide enough horsepower to last you at least 4-5 years.- At 13.2oz it’s incredibly light but yet still feels durable in your hands. The anti-slip coating on the back helps to ensure you don’t accidentally drop it, although a protective case is still a good idea!- MAYDAY!!! Actually quite a cool feature. If you ever have trouble finding something, running something, or just need help using your HDX, Mayday connects you directly to an Amazon rep who can help.Cons:- No Google apps or Google features (only a problem if you’re mobile world is heavily influenced by Google; pictures, contacts, etc)- Although very minor, the interface can provide some confusion on where things are located. Ie, “Home”, “Back”, “Settings”, etc.What's the difference between this and other android tablets?- The biggest thing...amazon controls the software, the updates, and the apps you can install. It's easiest to think of this as a tablet devoid of anything "Google" that loves to play in the realm of “Amazon”. This isn't really good or bad; it just depends on how you see it and what you're used to (keep reading).Google versus Amazon:- Originally when the Amazon app store launched you were hard-pressed to find all the apps found in the Google store. But, now that the Amazon app store has taken serious leaps forward you can pretty much find any app you’re looking for. However, I strongly recommend that you look through the Amazon app store (Shop by Department -> Amazon App Store) FIRST to make sure any specific apps you’re needing are there before you purchased a Kindle HD/HDX. You may have that one unique android app that’s only available in the Google play store.- If you’re use to the world of Google (Contacts, Apps, Photos, Syncing, etc) then a Kindle HDX may not be right for you…if you want an Android tablet to complement your Android device collection (Phone, Tablet, etc). Having used Android phone since v1.1, I found that there were things I wasn’t getting with the Kindle HDX that I would have wanted. Thing like “Automatic Contacts sync”, “Picture syncing”, etc. Not that these are deal breakers, it just I would have preferred to have consistency between all my devices. However, Amazon does offer cloud backups for photos and contacts, however, if you have an Android phone before a kindle, you may find yourself frustrated with having to manage two separate contact lists and photo collections. All in all, if you’re use to the Google way of handling things, using Amazon’s apps may prove to be frustrating and monotonous.Summary:- All in all this is a beautiful tablet and completely different from the first Kindle Amazon created. While it harkens back to the Kindle days, it’s best to look at this tablet as a complete redesign of the whole kindle “experience”. While the lack of Google features (pictures, contacts, etc) can provide some headache, the seamless integration of Amazon’s Video streaming, Lightning Deals, App Store, and Kindle apps makes it surprisingly simple and easy to use. At 13.2oz it’s incredibly light but yet feels sturdy in your hands. Battery life is great considering the CPU and Video resolution and the quality and color of the screen certainly makes it one of the top “Most Beautiful Screens to Look At”. If you’re use to Google’s ways of handling things (pictures and contacts), the Kindle HDX will most likely be best suited as an E-book reader, occasional Prime Instant Video watcher, and large screen gaming device. If you’re new to the Google world, making the transition to using Amazon’s cloud-based apps probably won’t be that difficult! Hands down, for a price tag of $379, the Kindle HDX 8.9” is a beautiful tablet worth owning.
Reviews.Title: Android Tablet...or a Kindle Fire HDX?

Reviews.Author: aam in ak
Reviews.Content: I am not new to Kindle, having purchased and used every kindle (except the DX) from the beginning.  I currently own 2 paperwhites (an original and the new one).I bought 2 Fire 8.9 HDXs, one 32 gig for my son, a 64 for me, ad free- wifi only and spent a small fortune to do so.The positives (5 star)- screen clarity is beyond awesome- responsiveness to touch excellent, weight non-existent, Mayday was very polite.The negatives- and they are big ones for me  (heavy digital user of magazines and newspapers)- so 1 star or less.1)  Amazon does not allow you to download ALL of your magazines to your device, only the current issue and ONE prior.  This is not disclosed, and in fact since an option in Manage Subscriptions is to download prior issues to any device on your account, NOT allowing it is highly misleading.  I spent an hour "chatting" with support and was told (basically) "too bad" then support from Mayday.  I have 27 subscriptions and have been purchasing digital content since the first Fire came out, then the iPad2 for the last two years (larger screen for older eyes).  Let me be clear- if anyone at Amazon is reading this-  I PURCHASED the content and it belongs to me.  I did not "rent" the right to view it at your convenience.  As far as I am concerned- digital issues are no different than paper issues which I would have kept on the bookshelf.  The nice lady at Mayday said that there is a "server" issue and that the cloud is always available.  Unfortunately, it is not always available for me (in Alaska), nor is it available in many rural places I travel.  Since I sold back my ipad 2 to amazon to defray the costs of this purchase, I now feel robbed of my content.2.  The lack of Google apps is a HUGE problem for my middle school son .  I thought I would be able to side-load the stuff he needs, but cannot.  His school requires access to google docs for collaborative projects, and we are frozen out.  Thank goodness we still have an old iPad 1.  If Amazon wants to push this as a student tablet, they need to find a way to play in the sandbox with google, period.The upshot-I am deeply frustrated with the potential of the Fire HDX, and HOPE Amazon fixes the issues so the ecosystem lives up to the hardware.  Until that happens, these are really just toys, and do not replace the iPad for functionality.So sad...UPDATE to 5 starsIn the month since my first post, I have Found work arounds for the google issue, not having my mags is still frustrating, but this tablet has become a go-to device for both work and home.  Using ighome to replace my old home screen, I have access to my Google calendar for work.  Same workaround for my son and the schoolwork he needs access toWe do not pine for the iPads at all
Reviews.Title: updated -does not live up to the marketing hype. I was wrong

Reviews.Author: The King of Nothing
Reviews.Content: Like many others, this isn't anywhere near my first tablet.  Nor, is it my first Fire.  I've modded, rooted, and sideloaded nearly every android thing I've owned, yet, I have no desire to do that with this iteration of the Fire.  There has been so much written about it, so a full review is excessive, but these are my quick thoughts.First, the hardware is as advertised.  Right now, it's simply the most powerful and beautiful tablet available.  It's fast and images are gorgeous.  Text has laser printer like clarity.  Movies look great, and the sound, wow.  The Dolby audio is something to hear.  No joke, on the first movie I watched on my new HDX, there was a bird in the background, and I honestly started looking around the room for it.  It is excellent.Seconds, the FireOS is actually pretty good!  I'm a fairly knowledgeable android ROM tinkerer, but I don't see any real problems with the FireOS, at least nothing that has me actively looking to fix it.  It's a pleasantly surprising modded Android experience.  Plus, there are some real benefits of keeping it stock and using your Prime membership.I owned the Fire 1.0 and sold it pretty quickly.  It felt weak and very restricted.  The HDX is the polar opposite, it's a beast, and I'm enjoying it very much.
Reviews.Title: Awesome, awesome tablet.  From a tech nerd.

Reviews.Author: K. Brown
Reviews.Content: Got the 32GB model without ads with the quarterly payment option (otherwise, don't think I would have sprung for it).  Let's start out with the good: Extremely thin and light weight, awesome screen, easy setup and navigate. Now the not so good: Battery charger included...but it is the slow 5w charger, not the fast 9w powerfast charger (at least that is what the pop-up window indicated when I plugged it into the charger). But on the other hand, I guess charging it up overnight should be enough for a full charge by morning? So far, I am very pleased with the purchase and would highly recommend this device. Glad to see Amazon using an installment program plan...5 stars for that alone, got me off the fence to make a purchase!
Reviews.Title: Big improvement over the previous model

Reviews.Author: rsawey
Reviews.Content: First, let me say that I am a big fan of Amazon in general and Kindles in particular.  My new HDX is the 5th Kindle that I have owned, so I have drunk deeply of the Amazon Kool-Aid, and likely won't be leaving the Amazon ecosystem any time soon.However, if you use your Kindle to read newspapers, do NOT buy the HDX.  Why? Because the newspaper reader on this device does NOT have the "Sections" drop-down menu.  I've verified this with the a very cheerful Mayday consultant.  It wasn't just hidden somewhere.  It just was not there.All of my previous Kindles have had this feature, and I've come to rely on it, particularly when I'm reading a large newspaper such as the "NY Times."  Before, if I wanted to go directly to the "Business" section, I could drop down the menu, touch and be there.  Now I have to scroll and scroll and scroll to get there, being very watchful that I do not go past the section header, a header in a smaller and light font.  In what software design universe is this to be considered an improvement?I really hope the software designers fix this.  For now, I'm reading my newspapers on my old original Kindle Fire.
Reviews.Title: If you read newspapers on your Kindle, do NOT buy the HDX

Reviews.Author: Pia
Reviews.Content: I bought the kindle as a Christmas gift for myself. I tried to be ahead of the big shopping extravaganza after Thanksgiving and was at first a little bummed when I was told that it would take almost 3 weeks to deliver the tablet. But then I received almost every day a new email, letting me know that the delivery was sooner. It was finally scheduled to be shipped on 12/02 but I received it on 11/30. Made me feel good, barely a week after the order.I received the tablet, plugged it in, turned it on and it worked. A few things gave me a bit of a hard time to figure out, there was no written manual. But there is the 'mayday' button on the tablet. And it worked, just as promised. I hit the button I waited may be 10 sec and I talked to somebody who helped me fix my problem.I've borrowed books through my library, sent emails, updated my facebook page, downloaded a few knitting patterns and transferred others from my desktop to the kindle, I have subscribed to the e-version of a magazine, I read my daily newspaper on the kindle, I watch my Netflix shows on it. I have installed and played a few games.I love the ability of the kindle to read books to me (even if I am not using an audiobook). I'm reading my favorite novel and I need to do dishes, so I can let the tablet read to me and do whatever it is I need to do. Also the instant lookup capabilities are wonderful. I'm bilingual German/English, I can have words (from my novel) translated into german or look the term up in a dictionary or even on Wikipedia - just by touching it on the screen.The cameras (front and back) are fun to play with and I managed to get a few pictures from my notoriously camera-shy dog - she didn't even realize that I was taking a pic of her. I have yet to play with the abilities of the machine to accept commands from the distance, haven't yet gotten around to it.I had no problems connecting Bluetooth devices or set it up for my home-wifi network. The machine doesn't lock up, it doesn't crash, the 2 or 3 things I had were my issues of not knowing and they were resolved by the help I received through the almost instant mayday button.The one thing that annoys me a bit (and I guess that's not the kindle but the amazon shopping page) is that I only can look for books by keywords, but not by let's say author and publishing years (or other more specific things). I receive too many results when I'm looking for something specific. But that's really a minor issue.I'm still discovering every day new things to do with the tablet and it is fun.If I had to describe a really positive shopping experience - this would be it.If I had to describe a tablet that does what I want it to do - this is it.Thank you.
Reviews.Title: Very satisfied and having a lot of fun with the little machine

Reviews.Author: Brian C. McCall
Reviews.Content: Update (12/10/13):After replacing the 64 GB model with the 32 GB model I have not experienced any of the previous issues I had. I have used it for several weeks now and everything works as you would expect. I have updated my rating to 2 stars because while the 32 GB model works, it is not what I wanted and the 64 GB model is, as far as I know, still severely flawed and essentially DOA.Previous review:There is a major problem with this model (64 GB, Wi-Fi). I have had 3 of these so far. You read that right, 3. All have exhibited the same problem. I download Prime Instant Videos and can watch them but once I attempt to delete them, the tablet becomes bricked and totally unresponsive. It will not power back on. Amazon customer service has been quick to replace them but clueless as to what the problem actually is. Do not buy this model if you plan on downloading Prime Instant Videos because you will just end up sending it back, bricked.
Reviews.Title: Buyer beware!

Reviews.Author: Donna J. Krein
Reviews.Content: We purchased the Kindle HDX, our first ever tablet.  The screen flickered and would take you back to home screen when browsing Internet. After 3 May Day calls and still no resolution we requested to return and try another unit. Bad decision, second unit did same thing. Is it the HDX model? Friends have the Kindle Fire and love them. We wanted to love the HDX but they need to debug them before sending them out to folks.  Now in search of a different tablet, not a Kindle, sorry Amazon.
Reviews.Title: Not what we hoped for

Reviews.Author: gadjetGirl59
Reviews.Content: Amazon keeps improving their product, Kindle 8.9 HDX is a fine piece of hardware.  I received my tablet Thursday and finally have been able to play with it.  First off, this thing is light, very light, one hand light!.  I had the 1st and 2nd gen Kindle fires and this HDX is a delight to hold.  I have a Samsung 8.9 and is about the same size but the HDX still feels lighter.  I will admit to owning the iPad4 and in my opinion the screen looks clearer and sharper.  The hdx's screen is gorgeous, just gorgeous.  Crystal clear, color is just beautiful and looks just as good as my HDTV.I did get the Origami cover but it adds weight so I will probably send it back.The browser is much faster than the last tablet, just breezes through the pages.  And no stuttering when changing to different sites.  The sound is good, maybe not as loud as the hd, but I normally use earbuds anyway.  But even turned up all the way, there is no distortion.  I was able to down load drop box (able to access content), 1Mobile app, Hulu plus (plays fine), and some other favorites. I do find that their are some apps that have not been updated for the hdx but I assume all good things take time. So no worries. :-)I have opened books to read, NO blue or purple tint.  I even used MayDay because I thought I had a problem downloading the update.  The C/S rep was very nice.  I do not know why people are rating this tablet low, this tablet is a keeper!!
Reviews.Title: Kindle 8.9 hdx is Awesome!

Reviews.Author: Charlie G
Reviews.Content: I've had the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 for almost a week and find it a joy to use.  My first reaction when taking it out of the box was how light it is!  The next reaction is its thinness and form factor...you have to marvel at the feel of that thin body but it also seems sturdy (I did try to gently flex the body but it didn't flex).  Then I tried out the new power button which is a great improvement over the Kindle Fire HD 8.9...easy to locate (in spite of the fact it is on the back of the left side), in an intuitive location and easy to depress.  When the screen comes alive it is exceptionally sharp, colors are vibrant and even smaller text is easy to read.  After the set-up which was straight forward, I got to test the new faster processor and was pleasantly surprised...FAST and SMOOTH!  At this point I start rapidly going from one app to another app to calendar to email and the HDX stays with me without lag...this is the real deal!  Now to access the internet...very smooth.  Now I decide to stream a movie from my video library and again smooth and no lag, really good sound quality and...yes, that beautiful screen.  Ok, now for playing music from the cloud...I select a song, it starts playing and the words to the song are displayed as the song progresses which falls into the neat factor category.  I then had a question, looked at the built in manual which didn't provide the answer so I tried out Mayday.  Just as advertised I had tech support on the screen within 15 seconds and after a short explanation of my question the tech talked me through the solution...even taking over the screen for a moment to show me something.  Amazon is on to something with this Mayday...you do not have to experience frustration if you bump up against an issue you can't quickly resolve on your own.  The tech support is friendly, empathetic and anxious to solve your issue...and it happens almost instantly.  For non-technical people this is a particularly wonderful benefit of owning an HDX!!  Amazon's competition should be worried about this feature of customer service.I am not yet sure what to make of Amazon's decision to not include an HDMI out which I used on my HD 8.9 and enjoyed a lot.  I have ordered a miracast compatible device for my tv and will see if that provides the same quality of mirroring that I got with an HDMI cable linked between my HD 8.9 and the tv.  More to be revealed.UPDATE ON MIRACAST DEVICE:  I received the Netgear Push2TV miracast device and after hooking it up to the tv (without firmware update) and connecting the Kindle Fire HDX for mirroring mode, the mirroring was excellent!  Movies streamed from my Library on the Amazon cloud to the Kindle Fire mirrored to the tv without any latency.  Everything else including web surfing, display of photos (either on device or on the cloud), music, etc. mirrored flawlessly.  I attempted the firmware update but ultimately had to call Netgear tech support due to very poor instructions that come with that product(I will deal with that in a review of that product).  So, Amazon's decision to not include an HDMI out is justified based on my experience with mirroring.So, my early reaction to the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 is that it is very light, thinnnn and very responsive.
Reviews.Title: Light, Fast and Smooth

Reviews.Author: Peter R. Forshay
Reviews.Content: My Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" became unresponsive while trying to delete videos.  It then shut itself off and won't turn back on.  Amazon support tried one restart cycle (hold the power button for 20 sec, then press once more to turn on) and gave up.  Of course it is out of stock at the moment, so the replacement won't get here before leaving for Thanksgiving travel, which I specifically ordered it for.  Time for a refund I guess.It also might be worth noting there is no gmail app.  It's not a deal-breaker, but surprised me.UPDATE (Nov 20)Amazon reported more 8.9" HDX in stock shortly after my initial support call.  They are currently rushing me a replacement to get here before I leave for vacation.  I'll update my rating if the replacement works.  One of the support emails I received also indicated they have been able to recreate the issue with deleting Prime videos and are working on a fix, for what it's worth.
Reviews.Title: Broke after 48 hours

Reviews.Author: Illusionofcntrl
Reviews.Content: The HDX hardware is great. It's amazing to me the advancements in 12 months (seems like Moore's law is 4 x's faster with tablet tech) when comparing the HDX against the HD. Not only is the HDX much faster and lighter, it just feels better. Don't get me wrong, I'm a fan of the HD, but the HDX is just much more refined. The HD now feels clunky in my hand (if that makes sense). The HDX is feather light, and well trimmed it fits better than the previous generation. Peformance, it's running a snapdragon 800 quad core processor it's fast. Noticeably faster than the previous generation HD. Graphics are as advertised. The device is top notch from a hardware and look and feel. The 8.9" form factor can't be beat it is the right size for a tablet.The addition of the volume and power button on the back is a step in the right direction. The addition of the rear facing camera another positive (it takes great pics and vids and includes panorama). The custom Android OS Mojito 3.0 is smooth and well thought out.Overall, everything Amazon advertises about the device seems accurate. In my summation  it's flawed in only one way. However, this flaw will keep me from purchasing future Kindle fire devices. I would recommend making sure you are OK with this flawed approach before deciding to purchase. Much like the original Fire, the HD, and now the HDX does not allow access to the Play store. At first that might not seem like a big deal. Amazon has a decent app store with a fair amount of applications to chose from. However, if you like Youtube, Chrome browser, Battlefield 4 Commander, Gmail, and a host of other apps that many folks use daily you won't be able to get them easily. The worst part is that Amazon doesn't even give you the option to have access to the Play store (other tablet manufacturers do - Samsung). I'd be willing to void my warranty, or lose support for my device if they'd just give us the option of having access to the play store.Your options for getting the apps you want on your Kindle HD/HDX? You can side load. Which means getting the .apk from another device and loading it onto the Kindle. Using a couple of programs you can mostly side load fairly easily once you know how. It works but any updates to the application and you will have to complete the process again (if you want the most current version) and application are updated often. Your second options is to load an alternate app store like 1mobile. The risk of this is that you will increase your chance of downloading an app that includes malicious software. This can happen on the play store as well, but it is more likely to occur on alternative app stores.Strongly consider this weakness before purchasing. If I had play store option, I'd give the Kindle Fire HDX 5 stars. Without it, I can only give 3. If you want the applications that everyone uses, you need to look elsewhere because the HDX might have great hardware but without the applications you will be limited. It's a shame that Amazon has taken this approach.
Reviews.Title: Hardware is 5 star, lack of play store access continues to kill this great device

Reviews.Author: Kaio
Reviews.Content: I was an early adopter of the Toshiba Thrive tablet, and after only 2 years, it started getting wonky; (random screen flickers and CPU hiccups.)  So hubby and I decided to splurge and upgrade to the new Kindle Fire HDX.  This is the one and only Kindle Fire review I'll write, because it's the one and only Kindle Fire we plan to use until it bites the dust, which hopefully won't be for awhile.  I'm not just reviewing the HDX for self gratification and vote collecting; I'm writing this because it's finally in my hot little paws, and I genuinely love this tablet.There's an old Native tradition of extinguishing all campfires and going dark, prior to igniting the New Fire.  It's a time for reflection and rebirth, and very much how it felt rebooting our tablet experience; going dark until our new Fire HDX arrived.  So we extinguished our Thrive, offered it up to the Amazon Trade-In gods, and applied the gift card bestowed upon us to our HDX purchase.  Embracing the stillness of our techno-blackout, we postulated the coming spark of a New Fire and reflected on what we really wanted in a tablet.  We're avid Amazon customers, and figured it's time to make the most of it, so we upgraded to Amazon Prime ahead of our eminent Kindle experience.  There always seems to be perks for Kindle users, and we wanted in.  We came to realize that much had changed with tablets these past two years since we had our Thrive, and felt confident in our decision to take the leap with an HDX.  Amazon has a solid reputation for innovation, so when our trusty Thrive stopped being so trustworthy, Kindle Fire HDX was the first, and only, tablet we considered.When the brave delivery warrior pulled his steed up to the curb, my anticipation was palpable; my coveted precious had finally arrived!  I'd visualized this moment for weeks:  my new HDX cradled atop a velour and golden tussled pillow, shrouded by sunbeams and halos, angelic harps crescendo as trumpeters announce the entrance of my coveted new gizmo -- or perhaps it was just in a plain brown shipping box; I can't recall.  My heart was all aflutter, and I was effervescent with excitement, so I might be romanticizing the moment a tad.  Either way, all hail HDX!Is it just me? But whenever I open a new piece of tech, I get all tingly inside; cracking the outer seal, opening the box, getting a waft of that new toy smell -- a blend of fresh circuit boards, and static-free factory environments.  Not a spec of dust to be found as you peel back the protective stickies to reveal that glistening new gizmo. I see why they call it "Fire" because it feels smokin' hot in my grabby little paws.  In some ways, it feels like Amazon actually read my Thrive review and the exhaustive comment section, because I see many wish-list improvements implemented into this new Fire I'm anxious to ignite.> AmazoidAmazon's tablets are hybrid Android OS. Coming off my Thrive with Android ICS, this was the one area I was most concerned about. Would I like Amazon's hybrid; or would I miss my standard Android OS?  When I told a friend we were getting an HDX, she was surprised, "you're both such avid techies, and Kindle Fire seems to be less than a full-fledged tablet."  Our friend wondered if we'd miss having a true Android experience.  We had the same concerns, at first, but then started to wonder, what is a "true" Android experience anyway?  Different menus and a home screen? Pffft!Sure, Amazoid is a bit of an adjustment; it's completely idiot-proof and more closely mimics what little exposure I've had to Apple iOS, with the addition of carousels.  I'm still a bit concerned that Amazon's hybrid will be overly restrictive, compared to my Android experience, but so far, I like it.  Not having access to Google Play Apps may be the biggest adjustment, but I'm confident that I'll figure out an acceptable workaround, or just learn to live without.  Truthfully, I rarely visit Google Play anyway, and don't need access to endless dreck and borderline malware apps.  I already rent and buy all my movies and books here on Amazon, so other than possibly a few specialty apps, Google Play won't be missed.As far as the OS and my "true" experience with it, Android hasn't been around long enough for this to be a huge change for me.  An OS is like a tablecloth -- you need it to dress and protect the table, but hardly notice it once the meal arrives.  In reality, I do far less geek stuff with my tablets than I do with my laptops, so I think I'm good with the lateral OS shift. Even Windows 8 has made the lateral shift to a more homogenized OS experience, (though I far prefer Win 7,) and iOS is literally giving away the latest iteration of their Mac operating system.
