So like it or not, the trends are clear: the all-mighty OS isn't the crown jewel it used to be; sure, it matters to share holders, but doesn't add up to much for rest of us.  It's about the gizmo, not the set dressing.  Homogenized operating systems are here to stay, and ultimately, it's a good thing.  And you can bank that future iterations of Android will follow these same trends.I'd say the differences between Amazoid and Android are negligible from a technical perspective; each has its advantages.  The biggest difference comes in the presentation and general user experience.  Fire is activity based, so the standard Android desktop has been streamlined to favor a more inviting and user friendly interface; clearly marked menus, pictorial carousels, all easy to follow and beckoning to be touched and explored.  Fire feels more like a consumer based experience, rather than a technological one.  Sure, Android is simple, but it still felt like I had the ability to do some computing, on some level.  But it also had its share of hiccups.  Whereas, Fire HDX, is a more controlled environment, centered around activities and experiences, yet with the versatility for productivity and business, and enough horsepower to please the nerdiest of geeks (like me, and the Big Bang clan.)  Fire's copy line, "Designed to do it all" pretty much covers it.  And I have to say, I'm quite impressed.> They Listened!The 'Zon actually cracked open the Suggestion Box!  Amazon reviews are a bit like trial by fire (coincidence?) in that, every flaw is magnified, and products live and die by customer commentary. From what I've witnessed in the exhaustive comments in my Thrive review, and read elsewhere about other tabs, Amazon seems to have actually paid attention to what's being said in our complaints and wish lists, and tried to address the most common issues. Fire HDX has clearly built upon it's multi-generation iterations; it's refined, elegant, very well thought out, and precisely executed.  This is the tablet I wanted in the first place. The only thing missing, is a replaceable battery, which would have been cool (hint-hint, Amazon) but likely unachievable given the sleek design.> Second ScreenI got the Thrive primarily for 2 reasons - ports, and a replaceable battery.  Turns out, I didn't use the ports nearly as much as I thought I would; the full size HDMI was just a pain, because I'd rather have wireless.  Enter Fire HDX -- Amazon made the genius move of adding what essentially adds up to wireless HDMI -- wish granted; thanks Amazon!  Second Screen can play movies or content from your Fire, directly on your HDTV, freeing up your tablet's screen to check email, fling some Angry Birds, or just control the video on your HDTV with Fire's play, pause, etc. controls.  Sweet!  I have an HTPC setup, so not sure how meaningful Second Screen will be for me in the long run, but I can't wait to really delve into it!  Definitely a high-end, trend-setting feature; Gold Standard, for sure.> MiracastSimilar but different to Second Screen. This feature wirelessly mirrors your Fire's screen on your HDTV. I liked doing this with my Thrive, but came to hate the HDMI cable tying me down. You haven't really experienced Angry Birds until you play it on a 50" screen! We definitely will be looking for Miracast accessories.  Just a natural addition to my HTPC setup, and sure to be another Gold Standard option others will copy. Yet another indication that Amazon went all out with Fire HDX, and this geek is impressed.> Anorexically ThinOnly, in this case, that's a good thing.  Fire HDX is literally half the thickness of my Thrive, and half the weight too.  I loved the grabby feel of my Thrive, but over time, I admit it was awkward due to the thickness and weight; especially inside the case.  It was like carrying a textbook.  Fire HDX is thin, but doesn't feel like I'm holding a metal tray, or a techno exoskeleton. It's comfortable in the hands and feels solidly built.  And it's svelte silhouette makes it super easy to tuck away and take on the go.> Screen of Tech GodsThe Fire HDX screen is a nerd guru's dream, and anyone possessing the gift of sight will appreciate it's beauty and clarity. Stunningly vibrant, excellent viewing angles, dripping with saturation; I wish my HDTV had pictures this good.  The screen on this HDX is clearly the crown jewel of all it's impressive specs; it's just that good. Words simply don't do it justice.***Hey Amazon*** - How about making a 60" Kindle HDTV with a stunning screen to rival my new HDX?? Goosebuuumps!!> 10.1" vs. 8.9" vs. 7"I thought I might miss my Thrive's 10.1" screen.  Truthfully, I hardly notice the transition to 8.9".  The slightly smaller size helps make HDX lighter, thinner and easier to handle.  Plus the difference in screen quality is so stark, that I could care less that HDX is 1.2" smaller than my old Thrive.  The 7" HDX is just downright cute!  Hubby really loves it because he thinks it'd be easy to slip into his cargo pants pockets and take on the go. He may get one, but for now, we settled on the 8.9", which has proven to be the absolute perfect size.> No Screen Protector RequiredI'm usually a big fan of those military engineered, 'helicopter blade' screen protectors.  However, I have NO plans to dilute or mar the beauty of this gorgeous HDX screen!  Much as I believe in screen protectors, in this instance, I liken it to keeping a posh leather sofa in plastic. This screen is far too nice not to enjoy it as it was meant to be seen. No way, no how, am I covering this beauty with a ten buck screen protector.  Besides, I trust my Origami Case to protect my HDX in style.  If a worthy screen protector presents itself, I might consider it; but for now, it's 'au naturel,' baby.> 16gb vs. 32gb vs. 64gbIf you want to make a budget friendly decision, this is the place to make it. I'm glad Amazon didn't bother making an 8gb tablet; utterly useless.  16gb is decent, but you will definitely have to keep an eye on your storage.  And keep in mind, storage tends to get wonky the closer it gets to full capacity; so be sure to leave yourself some room to spare.  64gb was tempting, especially if I start getting into downloading movies.  But personally, I sprung for the 32gb as it fit my budget and needs best.  I was only using 14gb on my old 32gb Thrive, so I knew 64gb was an indulgence, not a necessity.  And I'm not exactly conservative with what I'll load up on my tablet.  I delete apps I don't use, simply because I no longer want them, not because I need to conserve space.  And I already loaded my HDX with 5gb of Michael Jackson MP3s alone, so I'm not shy about taking advantage of the storage I've got.  Yes, I do own a 5gb waft of Amazon's Cloud storage, but I'm the kinda guy who doesn't want to put their faith in a solid internet connection being available at all times.  Hiccups happen.  I do use the Cloud for some stuff, but local files can be played anywhere, at any time, no hiccups, no data fees. The Cloud is good for storage and convenience, but when it comes to my most important and frequently used files, I want them stored locally for guaranteed access and privacy.*Even Better: Seagate Central 2gb Personal Cloud - access your files from anywhere in the world.  Works great!***Cloud Tip*** - Sure, the cloud is great for storage and convenience, but just don't be surprised when that "breaking news" hits about how these tech companies are reading all your documents and looking at all your "private" files.  It's been happening since the McCarthy era, at least; now with modern tech.  If I can track my own GPS location and activate my tablet or cell phone's cameras remotely, then I expect others to be able to do the same.  As we know, Amazon 'targets' all of us quite effectively, so it's hardly a big shocker to think others can do the same.  I expect no less, and am somewhat ok with it when people I trust are in charge, and not so thrilled when it's the other guys. If you wanna keep something private, then keep it off the Cloud and keep it to yourself.  It's that simple.> Great Dual CamerasHere's another area where Thrive just sucked over time. I didn't mind the lack of a flash at first, but it soon proved to be a real pain.  Conversely, the dual cams on my HDX take excellent quality pictures. The focus is great, and doesn't take long to zero in on the target.  And the dreaded delay most gadgets have after taking a pic is miniscule to nonexistent.  The LED flash is a HUGE Bonus!  I really came to miss that on my Thrive.  The menus and pic galleries are well laid out, and renderings are fast; just a pleasure to work with all around.***Privacy Tip*** - Keep tabs on what your front facing camera is doing!  My Thrive's front cam used to kick in all on its own, and the little LED would come on, alerting me that the camera was active. Either this was a tech glitch, a rogue app, outright nut-job, or Big Brother was watching every once in a while.  I ended up placing a sticker over the lens since I rarely used the front cam anyway, and didn't like the idea of being spied on by Edward Snowden, or the like. Haven't noticed anything like that with HDX, but I got my eye on it.  So, look sharp, people; that front facing camera may not always be your friend.> Wifi vs. 4g vs. TetheringIt all depends on your needs. 4g will have ongoing fees, and arguably, isn't needed with all the WiFi Hotspots popping up.  (Google is literally launching WiFi balloons into the atmosphere!)  Plus, I'm not fond of Verizon or AT&T.;  (More of a Sprint fan, particularly their budget offshoot, Boost Mobile.)  But if your budget is ok with the data fees, and your needs require it, then go for the 4g model. Just be aware, there are alternatives.Personally, WiFi is all I need. And HDX's dual band antenna really does work quite well; connections are great, with excellent range. However, I do occasionally need the convenience of a 4g data connection, but I do it so infrequently, that an outright data plan is just indulgent.  Besides, I already have a cell phone with unlimited data, and don't feel I should have to pay for that feature twice.  My solution?  I just got the LauncherPro App for my cell phone, found the hidden menu that enables tethering without rooting, and voila -- I can tether my HDX to my cheapo LG Marquee Boost Mobile phone wherever I want; all with unlimited data for $40 bucks a month.  (If you're curious on how to do the same, just poke around a little with LauncherPro on your Android phone; you'll figure it out.  Google search is your friend.)  Truthfully, I rarely tethered my Thrive, but I like knowing I have the capability if needed with this new HDX.  It's more cost effective than being saddled with outright 4g, and I'm not stuck choosing between 2 cell companies I don't like much.***Dear Amazon Gods*** - I've been a very good boy this year.  And I need a good pay-as-you go cell phone.  Kindle Mobile please?  If it's as well thought out and constructed as HDX, I'm in! And pretty please - don't price gouge us by charging extra for tethering.  Tablets are just oversized cell phones when it comes to how they process data.  So just let us tether for free, will ya?  Thanks; cookies and milk are on the table. Love, Kaio> Rooting - Don't Do It!I used to be a fan of it, now I'm not. Frankly, you're putting a lot of faith in the people who created the hacks (yes, "rooting" is just a euphemism for "hacking.")  Personally, I'd rather not trust complete strangers to imbed whatever hacks they've created into a tablet I use for banking. I'm just funny that way.  And since I figured out how to tether with my cell phone via the hidden menus, rooting became obsolete in my world.  Plus, the ROMs never offer all that that much really, and certainly not all the hackers claim; like improved battery life. It's more about driving website traffic to the host sites, and entertaining clever ROM gurus, rather than any tangible benefit, IMO.These guys are smart, no doubt about it -- that's what scares me.  I'm not interested in being some tech genius' beta tester, nor do I care to unleash their rogue code into my devices and willingly breach its security.  Chances are, it's all good and harmless ...probably ..maybe.  But for me, the slim benefits hardly merit the lingering doubt.  The few ROMs and hacks I've tried literally needed me to turn off my firewalls and security software just to work with them, because by definition, they are Trojans.  Sorry, but I'm just not that trusting anymore.  So, ixnay on the rooting for me, thanks much. Proceed at your own risk.Having said that, I would consider rooting if I end up hating the more restrictive Amazoid experience, or decide I just can't live without Google Play Apps.  But at this point, I seriously doubt I'll do it.  I just don't trust it.  Plus, I already know how to get the apps I want onto the HDX directly, including Google play, all without rooting, so I'm not worried.***No-Root Tip*** - I'm not going to advise anyone on how to tweak their HDX, so there's no need to ask.  But I will point ya'll in the right direction -- Google "how to side-load apk's" and you'll figure out the rest pretty easily on your own.  If that doesn't work, I'm 100% confident there's another workaround that doesn't require rooting.> Amazon Fresh AppSpeaking of apps, I consider it a privilege to live in an area where Amazon Fresh is available.  Ordering groceries and electronics from my HDX for same day delivery is pretty dreamy; we just LOVE it!  We've been getting grocery delivery, on and off, for years now, so the switch to Amazon Fresh fits our lives perfectly.  The app works great, and we love seeing all the new green trucks humming around town; cannot recommend this service highly enough -- go Amazon Fresh!***Tip - Other Must-Have Apps***-- WiFi Analyzer App - use this to test the WiFi signals around any of your WiFi environments.  Find the best sweet-spots for optimal connections.  If you're super adventurous, get a couple of High Gain Antennas for your router and watch your signal spike!  Just be sure to enable MAC filtering to keep any pesky neighbors from slipstreaming your network.-- Kaspersky One - Antivirus and Internet Security for 5 devices under one low-cost license; any combo of PC, tablets and phones, up to 5 devices.  The app itself can be loaded via a direct link from Kaspersky or the included QR code.-- Team Viewer - remotely control your PC with your tablet while away from home!  Easily transfer files from PC to PC, or even PC to MAC.  Works great. I've tried them all, and this one is still my fave overall. Can't wait to see HDX's iteration of this feature (coming soon!)And now, back to our regularly scheduled programming...> HDX Ergonomic AppealI love the way the volume and power buttons are placed; very natural and comfy to use.  This tablet was clearly designed to be held.  A lot of thought went into form following function, and how this tab naturally rests in my paws.  The weight is distributed well, and it just feels right to hold it; be it 1 or 2 handed.> Additional 2 Year WarrantyThis Verified Purchase would be your clue that I'm not just fishing for votes to up my reviewer rank; I'm a real HDX user, and this is my new day-to-day tablet for the foreseeable future.  I rarely buy extended warranties. I consider tech toys to be somewhat disposable, hence why I traded-in my Thrive as soon as I saw signs of age.  But Fire's extended warranty is actually worthwhile.  It covers accidental damage, and has free replacements shipped out prior to sending the damaged tablet back; replacements are probably refurbs, but still a nice touch.  The warranty also includes battery failure, screen cracks, and zero deductable. For 90 bucks, I'd say that's a good deal, so I sprung for it. Though, given my Thrive started to getting goofy at just 2 years old, I wish this warranty was for 3 years instead.  But I'll take it for the klutz factor, just in case.  (Check my review on the warranty product page if you're interested!)> Origami Case - The Cherry On TopIngenious! A true 'must-have' accessory. Love how it folds to accommodate multiple viewing positions. Love how it turns the HDX on and off automatically.  Love the feel, magnetic fit, and how the camera turns on automatically when you slide the tablet up.  At first, I wanted the polyurethane version, cuz I like the feel and SciFi look.  But I ended up going for the Blue Leather Origami Case because it just seemed classy.  An HDX without this origami case would just be incomplete. I love everything about this case and can't imagine owning the HDX without it.  Perhaps a tad overpriced, but that'll likely drop as HDX settles in.  More colors, please!> Cool SpeakersThe sound from HDX is surprisingly awesome. This is one area Thrive just sucked at, even with the Volume+ app.  But HDX is fantastic.  The custom Dolby really does enhance the fidelity, and I don't feel the need for any audio booster apps.  Naturally, if I wanna shake the house's foundation, I'll be using my home stereo.  But for tiny little speakers, I'd say HDX is as good as it gets. Plus, it's very cool how the origami case reflects the sound. Genius design. Amazon's really just showing off how clever they are with that one.  Kudos!> Where's My Charging Dock?I really liked the convenience of the dock for my Thrive and really thought I'd miss it.  But I'm guessing there will be plenty of goodies and accessories to buy for HDX. The good thing about standardization, like iPad, is that accessories are easier to come by. Same is true for Kindle. But I like the origami case so much, that I really see no need for the dock anymore. So I splurged the extra dough for the case, and have all but forgotten about my old charging dock.> USB Charging PortA universal USB charging port that works with most any standard charger?!?! What the!?  Give that genius a raise and a corner office!  HDX charges faster with the included charger, but nice to know I can use any USB charger handy, wherever I may be.***File Transfer Tip*** - I made a big to-do about wanting the convenience of USB ports to connect my Thrive to my laptops so I could easily transfer and backup files (too bad you couldn't charge via those ports.)  Newsflash - there's a whole bunch of apps out there that help you do direct file transfers to computers wirelessly (Astro File Manager and AirDroid are personal faves.)  Then there's DropBox and Amazon Cloud, so options are plentiful.  I'm a bigger fan of wireless than I am of wired, and have come to realize ports aren't as important as I first thought. Wireless HDMI, wireless file transfers between tablet and PC; Fire HDX is where it's at and I'm good to go!> Battery LifeThe truth of this one will be told over time, but for right now, I'm quite happy with it.  I'd say the 12 hour estimate is pretty close for me, though probably a bit less.  Screen brightness and data intensive apps will hit the battery hardest.  So naturally, I expect my battery life to fluctuate, depending on what I'm doing and how much luminosity I'm dripping from this gorgeous screen.  I just wish the battery was user replicable, but that likely wasn't possible with the ultra-thin body design.  Battery failure is truly is the one area I'm concerned about most; hence why I sprung for the extended warranty.> BluetoothI rarely use it on any of my devices. Just not a fan cuz I think it's one of the top causes of battery drain and OS abnormalities; faulty technology in IMO. But the signal seems fine. My array of stereo headphones sound good, paired smoothly, and stay connected, even from across the room.  But I expect these connections to get choppier outdoors; that's just how bluetooth is.  I predict (fingers crossed) the technology with soon be obsolete, in favor of something more reliable, with less power consumption.***Headset Tip*** - My fave stereo headphones, by far, is the Sony XBA-BT75. Killer sound and rich fidelity for such tiny bluetooth headphones; though nothing beats a thumping subwoofer that shakes the furniture.> Bang For Your BuckFire HDX has many cutting edge features that another nameless tablet would dole out once a year, and expect everyone shell out extra cash for each nominal upgrade. (P.T. Barnum fondly referred to people like this as "suckers.")  HDX is a trend-setting tablet, not a clone or follower.  This is the new Gold Standard, not a money pit.  If you're interested in what a tablet Does in the here and now, then get Fire HDX. If you're interested in owning a status symbol and being accepted by the cool kids, then, that circus is waiting for you.  I already graduated from high school and don't care to revisit that mentality.  Personally, I prefer substance over superficiality; I'm just funny that way.> Business ReadyCompared to HDX, the other Kindle Fires seem like toys. HDX 8.9, specifically, was clearly built for work AND play.  It comes preloaded with my fave OfficeSuite app for Word docs and all that good stuff.  And the specs under the hood are just unmatched.  Miracast and Second Screen would be invaluable in a meeting or presentation. And don't forget TeamViewer for accessing your work computer from anywhere in the world.> Powerhouse IndeedyI've never heard anyone complain that their computer is too fast.  Why buy such a powerhouse tablet? Because everyone, and I mean everyone, wants smooth, snappy and fast tech.  Unless your budget truly does not permit it, don't talk yourself into believing "I don't really need that for what I do."  Remember those words, and live by them, every time your computer or tablet hangs or hiccups.  Don't be the idiot who buys an $80 buck budget tab, and then complains that it doesn't work like iPad.  HDX is the perfect blend of budget and power.  There's just no reason to choose a sub-par gizmo.  The difference in price is nominal, the difference in performance is stark.  The quad core 2gb processor in HDX is an utter beast. It makes my dual core, 1gb Thrive seem like a sloth.  Remote Viewing apps are fast and smooth, as do games, videos, and all processor intensive apps I personally like.> External KeyboardsI'm really not a fan of them for tablets; probably because I hate glitchy bluetooth; invariably, keystrokes are frequently missed.  Besides, I like to touch my tab, even while typing. I do have a keyboard just in case though, and do use it once in awhile. But generally, I just don't see them as necessary for tablets. It just makes things awkward.  I've tried several, and this Logitech Tablet Keyboard is my fave.> MaydayA foolproof brain-fart button that connects you to Amazon Tech Support within 15 seconds. Yup, I tried it, and it works. So glad they couldn't see me in my undies ...I hope -- Eeek!  Another cutting edge, genius feature, sure to become a Gold Standard.> My Little, Preeeecioussssssss....Must have it, I did; love it, I do.  Oh, Kindle HDX; I'm so proud of what you've become. My every dream in a tablet come true; really and truly, that's not just gushing.  Oh ok, it is gushing, but I do mean it.  I just love my tech toys; especially this new HDX!> Accessibility FeaturesKudos, Amazon. As a disabled person myself, I am highly impressed by the screen reader and accessibility options, and your decision to feature them.  But you don't have to be disabled to benefit from them. Tired of squinting at tiny text? Try out one of these great accessibility features, like the screen reader or magnifier.> Read To Me BabyAbsolutely love the Immersive Reading feature and can't wait to really delve into it. Love that Kindle books now have a new way to be enjoyed. I have wanted this feature in a Kindle app since the day I got my Thrive, and so glad that Fire has it; HUGE bonus in my book.> Special Offers or No Special Offers?I debated over this one. It's only a 15 buck difference, and the feature can be turned off at any time by just paying the extra dough.  But I wanted to save a couple bucks, so I opted for the special offers.  Plus, I figure, I'm always shopping at Amazon, so a deal or two once in a while is probably a good thing. However, please keep the ads targeted, Amazon. Please don't start advertizing a bunch of crap to me that my purchase history does not justify. Keep it specific to my needs, and Never, Ever, automatically start playing movie trailers or outright commercials. If I wanna see them, I'll click on it; otherwise, silence is golden.  Last thing I want is my tablet berating me with blatant, noisy advertizing; making a big to-do about something I don't give a crap about. Otherwise, I'll just pay the 15 bucks and dump that feature in a blink.  Do, however, offer me coupons, promotions and deals for stuff you know I'm interested in.  Everyone loves a good coupon!> Holy TrollersYup, it's a real thing, and pretty much what it sounds like; a few highly motivated ones have been stalking me here on Amazon for years, and I'm bored of being 'effed with.  So I took a hiatus from comments a good while ago, and now just focus on trying to write good reviews.  Amazon's new question & answer format integrated into each product's page is a positive step in the right direction, and likely where I'd focus my time if I feel the urge. Perhaps this review will pull me out of my hiatus; so comment away!> Bottom LineThis review is my sizzle to Kindle's Fire; I hope I did this fantastic tab justice.  If you're still reading this, you deserve a prize; I have none for ya, but you deserve one all the same. Perhaps give yourself the prize of a Kindle Fire HDX; and don't forget to nab the Origami case! (Would you believe I even had to shorten this? Looks like I finally found Amazon's review limits.)Yes, I'm one of those nerds who gets excited by tech.  I'm not sure how valuable my skill set is in the real world, but I know gadgets, and HDX gives me goose bumps.  Stunning picture, fast processor and graphics, excellent sound, solidly constructed, superb design, ingenious origami case, and screen readers; plus, Gold Standard features like, Second Screen, Miracast and Mayday tech support -- this tablet is a dream.  Sunbeams, rainbows and angelic harps all over again.In a perfect world, I would have kept my old Thrive forever.  But I'm glad I traded it in while it could still be useful to someone, and was still worth a decent trade-in value to me.  (My gift card from Amazon Trade-In basically got me a free 2 year warranty and origami case for my new HDX.)  I'm thrilled to have made the leap to my new HDX, and absolutely love it!  Now, Amazon, please get busy on that Kindle TV and Kindle Mobile cell phone.  I want your iteration of those toys next! (No doubt they're already in the works.)>>Parting Thoughts<<Haiku of Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 32mb WiFi(*a-hem*).........origami cHictechno-electro-Docious..................maX-azon-azing!Updates likely to follow ...possibly ...maybe ...probably. Meh; whatever.Happy! ;oD*Disclaimer* - The opinions expressed in this review do not necessarily represent anyone whose opinion matters, anyone cares about, or that the author himself remembers typing, though he stands by each and every word vehemently.Time to go play ...HDX style!

Reviews.Title: Unbelieveable how much improved....

Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Finally, Amazon learned as how to make an excellent tablet. It has all the features you want - light enough to hold on one hand, best resolution in tablets, all the apps that most people use (I am assuming that 80% of the folks use 20% of the apps), outstanding exchange email app that sync contacts with facebook, front/rear facing camera and last but not the least - very fast.
